required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Interferon Alfa and Interleukin-6 in Treating Patients With Recurrent Multiple Myeloma
clinical_study.official_title: A Pilot Study of Differentiation Therapy in Multiple Myeloma Using Interleukin-6 and Interferon-a

lead_sponsor.agency: Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins

clinical_study.source: Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins

brief_summary.textblock:
RATIONALE: Interferon alfa may interfere with the growth of cancer cells. Interleukin-6 may stimulate the white blood cells to kill cancer cells. Giving interferon alfa together with interleukin-6 may kill more cancer cells.
PURPOSE: This clinical trial is studying the side effects and how well giving interferon alfa together with interleukin-6 works in treating patients with recurrent multiple myeloma.

detailed_description.textblock:
OBJECTIVES:
- Determine the response rate in patients with recurrent multiple myeloma treated with recombinant interferon alfa and recombinant interleukin-6.
- Determine the safety and optimal dose of this regimen in these patients.
- Determine the toxicity of this regimen in these patients.
- Determine the impact of this regimen on clonogenic growth of myeloma cells in serial in vitro assays.
OUTLINE: This is a pilot study.
Patients receive recombinant interferon alfa subcutaneously (SC) once daily. Beginning 1 month later, patients also receive recombinant interleukin-6 SC once daily. Treatment continues for up to 6 months in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.
PROJECTED ACCRUAL: A total of 27 patients will be accrued for this study.

primary_outcome.measure: Response Rate as Assessed by Number of Participants With Partial or Complete Response by Bladé Criteria.
primary_outcome.description: Number of participants with partial or complete response by Bladé criteria where partial response is defined as a >= 50% decrease in serum paraprotein or 90% decrease in urinary light chains (for participants without measurable serum paraprotein). Complete response is defined as negative serum and urine immunofixation and a bone marrow aspirate with < 5% plasma cells.

primary_outcome.measure: Toxicity as Measured by Number of Participants Who Discontinued Treatment Due to Adverse Events
primary_outcome.description: Number of participants who discontinued the protocol due to adverse events.
Maximum tolerated dose found using a standard 3+3 dose escalation model.

primary_outcome.measure: Impact of Treatment on Growth of Myeloma Cells
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 0, Day 14, Months 1, 2, 4, and 6 of combined therapy, and end of study
primary_outcome.description: Percentage change in growth of in vitro myeloma cells from baseline to end of study.

clinical_study.condition: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Neoplasm

arm_group.description: Subjects will be started on recombinant interferon-α at a dose of 3 million units SQ daily, escalating the dose by 1 million units every week as tolerated to a maximum dose of 3 million units/m2/day. Following a minimum of one month of interferon therapy with two weeks on a stable dose, subjects will begin recombinant interleukin-6 therapy at a dose of 2.5 ug/kg/day.

criteria.textblock:
DISEASE CHARACTERISTICS:
- Diagnosis of recurrent multiple myeloma
- Must have received ≥ 2 prior therapies
PATIENT CHARACTERISTICS:
- Performance status 0-3
PRIOR CONCURRENT THERAPY:
- See Disease Characteristics

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: One participant was a screen failure.

measure.title: Toxicity as Measured by Number of Participants Who Discontinued Treatment Due to Adverse Events
measure.description: Number of participants who discontinued the protocol due to adverse events.

outcome.title: Optimal Dose of Interleukin-6
outcome.description: Maximum tolerated dose found using a standard 3+3 dose escalation model.
outcome.population: This outcome cannot be evaluated as zero participants tolerated the study regimen. All participants were enrolled on the 2.5 mg arm and a maximum tolerated dose was not found.

group.title: Interleukin-6 and Interferon-α
group.description: Subjects will be started on recombinant interferon-α at a dose of 3 million units SQ daily, escalating the dose by 1 million units every week as tolerated to a maximum dose of 3 million units/m2/day. Following a minimum of one month of interferon therapy with two weeks on a stable dose, subjects will begin recombinant interleukin-6 therapy at a dose of 2.5 ug/kg/day. recombinant interferon-α recombinant interleukin-6

outcome.title: Impact of Treatment on Growth of Myeloma Cells
outcome.description: Percentage change in growth of in vitro myeloma cells from baseline to end of study.
outcome.time_frame: Day 0, Day 14, Months 1, 2, 4, and 6 of combined therapy, and end of study
outcome.population: Zero participants tolerated protocol therapy and the research sample blood draws were therefore not completed as planned. Because of this, the data from this outcome could not be collected.

reported_events.desc: Adverse events were assessed every two weeks through the first two months of combination therapy, then monthly through the end of the study.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
